introduction.p: These practice Gateway exams will help you prepare to successfully pass the Gateway Exam in Math 140 or Math 141.

These eight practice Gateway exams will help you prepare to successfully pass the Gateway Exam in Math 140. The derivative for each function, and the steps to obtain that derivative, can be viewed by clicking "Solution" under the function.

section.title: Practice Gateway Exam 1
section.p: The use of a calculator or any computer algebra system is not permitted on this test. No partial credit is available. A score of at least 7 correct is required to pass this gateway.
Find the derivative of each of the following functions:

solution.p:
Solution 1: Rewrite and use the chain rule.
h'(x) \amp = \frac{d}{dx}[(1+x^2)^{-1}]
\amp = -(1+x^2)^{-2} \cdot \frac{d}{dx}[1+x^2]
\amp = -(1+x^2)^{-2}\cdot 2x

section.title: Practice Gateway Exam 1
section.p: The use of calculators or any computer algebra system is not permitted on this test. No partial credit will be awarded. A score of at least 7 correct is required to pass this gateway.
Compute each of the following integrals.

solution.p:
Use substitution with u=2x^2+3 and du = 4x \, dx.
\int \frac{4x}{2x^2+3} \, dx \amp = \int \frac{1}{u} \, du
\amp = \ln|u| + C
\amp = \ln|2x^2+3|+C

Use substitution with u=5z and du = 5\, dz, so dz = \dfrac{1}{5}\, du.
\int 3e^{5z} \, dz \amp = \int 3e^u\cdot \frac{1}{5} \, du
\amp = \frac{3}{5} \int e^u \, du
\amp = \frac{3}{5}e^u + C
\amp = \frac{3}{5}e^{5z} + C

First decompose the integrand into partial fractions:
\frac{4}{x(x-2)} = \frac{A}{x} + \frac{B}{x-2}
This yields
4 = A(x-2) + Bx
Plug in x=2 to solve for B and x=0 to solve for A: 4 = 0 + 2B \implies B=2 4=A(-2) + 0 \implies A=-2 Now perform the integration
\int \frac{4}{x(x-2)}\, dx \amp = \int\left(\frac{-2}{x} + \frac{2}{x-2}\right) \, dx
\amp = -2\ln|x| + 2\ln|x-2| + C

Use integration by parts with
u \amp = 8t \amp dv \amp = \cos(t) \, dt
du \amp = 8 \, dt \amp v \amp = \sin(t)
Then
\int 8t \cos(t) \amp = 8t\sin(t) - \int 8\sin(t) \, dt
\amp = 8t\sin(t) + 8\cos(t)+C

Use substitution with u=x^4+5 and du = 4x^3 \, dx, so x^3 \, dx=\dfrac{1}{4} \, du.
\int 2x^3(x^4+5)^6 \, dx \amp = 2\int u^6 \cdot \frac{1}{4} \, du
\amp = \frac{1}{2} \frac{u^7}{7} + C
\amp = \frac{(x^4+5)^7}{14} + C

Use substitution with u=4x+7 and du = 4\, dx, so dx = \dfrac{1}{4} \, du.
\int \sqrt{4x+7} \, dx \amp = \int u^{1/2} \cdot \frac{1}{4} \, du
\amp \frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{u^{3/2}}{3/2} + C
\amp = \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{2}{3} (4x+7)^{3/2} +C
